choices: Virtual knots.
Flat Reidemeister moves.
Yoshikawa moves.
Knot diagrams on oriented surfaces.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, the letters a, b, c, and d represent:
choices: Regions of a knot diagram.
Elements of a ternary quasigroup.
Types of crossings.
Both (A) and (B).

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 illustrates that when coloring regions of a link diagram on a surface:
choices: Regions passing over bridges have alternating colors.
The colors of regions passing over or under a bridge are unchanged.
Different ternary operations must be used for crossings above and below a bridge.
All regions adjacent to a bridge must have the same color.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of Figure 5, the notation X1X2X3T represents:
choices: The corner adjacent to the outgoing edges of a flat or positive crossing.
A specific element of the ternary quasigroup.
The result of applying the ternary operation T to elements X1, X2, and X3.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula implies that for flat link diagrams, the ternary quasigroups used will have:
choices: T and M as different operations.
T and L as the same operation.
T and M as the same operation.
No specific relation between T, L, and M.
